text:
I use a little more flavorful breading, 1cup of panko, 1cup of seasoned bread crumbs, and a cup of parmesan cheese with 2 tablespoons of finely chopped fresh parsley, a teaspoon of fresh chopped Thyme and a teaspoon of garlic powder. I brown the chicken in half butter and half olive oil. I also cook some angel hair while the chicken is browning, and put it under the chicken in a casserole dish, cover with foil and bake for 20 minutes, remove foil, add cheese and bake another 10 minutes

text:
3 stars because this was good with my common sense modifications. I do not know how any one of you got a good result as written. #1 - 4 c. of breadcrumbs?! Whoa! Not right. I used 1 c. plus 1/2c. shredded Italian cheese blend. #2. Recipe calls for 1/2c of sauce yet in directions you are to use 1/3c. x 4 chicken breasts...? You need to 'eye this up' and put enough sauce on each piece. #3 - You cannot use 1 c. of olive oil! Did you all do this? And you had a good result? The chicken would be swimming in oil! I used a little olive oil (maybe 2 TBS?) along with a TBS of butter. #4 - Flour is not needed. #5 - Mozz cheese should be shredded, not 'fresh' for best melting result. #6- Don't put fresh basil on so early. It will burn - leave it for the last 5 min or use dried. Now, with these changes, the dish was delicious - but I guess it is now my own version of chicken parmesan.

text:
Have to admit if it's not easy and/or tasty I won't put the effort in. The WHOLE famiily loved this, and every recipe gets easier each time its' made, right?
I only used 1/2 the Panko. I didn't use the crumbs sparingly either. I only put 2 c in, and had the other 2 c in a bowl in case they were needed. I cut the chicken breasts in half before using the meat mallet. The fillet seemed too big without doing this, and it was easier for someone to have a second helping. I used Barilla Roasted Garlic sauce. I Loved the sifter for the flour; that worked great!
Given that I had twice as many fillets, next time, I would probably use half the oil, so I could have clean oil and maybe do the chicken in 2 batches. (I also used paper towels for excell oil.)
As much as I loved this recipe, given the calories/fat, I would not make it as often as I'd like.
10/2012- Just made this again for Sunday dinner, the family LOVES this recipe! I skipped/forgot the provolone this time around and used shredded mozzerella. Even though it's not as crispy, I made sure to have enough for leftovers. Also- use paper towels to collect extra oil after frying. TIP- If you buy chicken in bulk, then cut, trim, and pound with mallet before freezing for later use, this saves lots of time during actual recipe.

text:
Some time ago, I learned a useful trick: instead of steps 3-6 above, after the chicken breasts have been pounded and seasoned as in step 2, lightly brush both sides with heavy 33-35%MF whipping cream (use a pastry brush). Then transfer breasts to breadcrumb/Parmesan cheese mixture as made in step 4, pressing the crumbs into both sides.

I now use this method for virtually all recipes which call for breading, including fish, pork, veal, etc.  It is easier and less messy than using flour, eggs and milk to bind the breading to the meat and I have found that it works equally well.

text:
All I can say is Wow! I have made chicken parmesan using the most popular recipe from this site, but this recipe blew the other out of the park! This is a no brainer. My goal in writing this review is to let Members know that just because a recipe has a thousand hits/reviews, does not always mean its the best. I followed this recipe for the most part, however, made a few changes. I substituted regular bread crumbs and a jar of Classico traditional sweet basil. This turned out amazing! I used the entire jar of sauce because I served it over penne pasta. I put a thin spread of sauce on the bottom of the pan prior to placing the chicken inside. This recipe will definitely be a keeper and I won't hesitate to forward this recipe on to others. What a treat!

text:
Incredible dish! Great for dinner guests.  For those folks cooking in high altitude, 15 or 20 minutes is not quite enough to cook the chicken breasts.  You might want to cook them a little longer (6-7 minutes) on top of the stove or microwave them for several minutes (3 minutes)before serving.  Cut them in half to check doneness before serving. If you put them back in the oven for too long, the cheese might burn.

This Chicken Parmesan was so good that I ate the leftovers for breakfast the next day. I'm writing this review and giving my rating provided that I followed the directions of the recipe exactly as stated. I don't like reviews where people make a bunch of changes then rate "their" version. No thanks. This recipe is absolutely fantastic. There is not much more I can say. I have four kids ages 2-8 and they all loved it. I would stress the importance of pounding the chicken between the two plastic bags. It sounded strange to me but it makes a difference. Give yourself lots of time to make this meal. Its time consuming but worth it. I served it over angel hair, with sides of steamed broccoli and garlic bread. Yum!

Nice recipe! Was very much enjoyed at my house. 
I took some advice from other reviewers though, and spiced up the breading process a bit.  
Simply add a half teaspoon of salt, paprika, and pepper to the flour mix, and a dash or two of worchestershire to the beaten eggs.
Easy peasy!

text:
This recipe is fantastic! Although there are a few steps to take in terms of breading and then sautéing the chicken breasts, it was not difficult.  I had about one more chicken breast than called for but I still used about 1-1/2 cups of bread crumbs.  I did not have Panko so just used store brand and they worked perfectly.  Next time I will use the panko bread crumbs just to gauge the difference.  I used about 1-1/2 cups of bread crumbs and just slightly more parmesan than the 1/2 cups (but not much more - I just had a bit extra from grating it).  I had read (may have been from another chicken parmesan recipe or here -- I can't remember right now) a tip about flouring the pounded fillets then refrigerating for about 1/2 hour before coating in egg (I used two) and then bread crumbs, so I did that. I did not leave the breadcrumbed chicken for the 15 minutes called for -- I somehow skipped over that instruction -- but the chicken browned beautifully anyway so I will leave that out in future too.  I put approximately 1/3 cup spaghetti sauce on each piece of chicken, then fresh mozzarella, and then a generous sprinkling of parmesan (freshly grated).  I did not put provolone but the end results were just fantastic.  After dinner I realized I'd forgotten the fresh basil too -- but although I'll add it next time, we sure didn't miss it this time.  I was so proud of how well the dish turned out and how delicious it was -- thank you, Chef John, for a wonderful recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
LazyChef

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe stands on its own, just the way it is.  That said, I recommend using only 2 cups of panko.  Why use $2 worth of crumbs when $1 worth will do?  I breaded the chicken twice, following the instructions -- and 2 cups of panko mixed in with 1/2 cup of Parmesan were plenty.  I deviated only slightly in a couple of other ways, which I'll share, just in case you're thinking of trying something similar.  First of all, being the penny-pinching cook that I am, I used only one egg and more than doubled the volume by adding it to a about 2 to 3 ounces of whole milk and beating/mixing them together with a fork.  The milk/egg mixture performed admirably in getting the breading to stick to the chicken.  Instead of frying the chicken in a pan of olive oil, I used my deep fryer, which always stands at the ready with peanut oil.  Using tongs, I gently lowered the chicken into the oil and cooked it at 375° F, one piece at a time for about 2 to 3 minutes each, until it turned a deep golden color.  By frying only one piece at a time, the chicken remained relatively flat and cooked nice and evenly.  (I will try olive oil someday just to see how the flavor changes, but the peanut oil worked well.)  I didn't have fresh basil, so I used dry basil and that was okay, but I think fresh would have been better.  Note: this recipe is all about the crispy breading. Covering chicken in foil while baking, as some do, will result in softer breading; if you like that, use cheaper (than panko) crumbs.

text:
I definitely know why this recipe has a full 5 star review - it's the best chicken parmesan I've ever had, let alone ever made..!  I followed the recipe as called for but did add a few extras. I used chicken tenderloins so I didn't have to pound them out and blotted the extra oil from the chicken after cooking in the skillet. I also grilled up some chopped onions and mushrooms which I sprinkled over the (homeade) spaghetti sauce layer and used fresh basil, parsley, rosemary & oregano for the seasoning. I served it over garlic spaghetti with garlic bread - Yum! Definitely will make again!

text:
Nicely done chef john! My wife just loved it and she is a little picky. I did the recipe exactly as shown, and didn't read one review out of respect for the man, chef John. I was also a huge fan. But I would modify next time ever so slightly for my taste. Lets remember that all chicken breasts are different, all tastes are different, and there are countless other variables that are different with every ingredient, stove, pan, cook etc. I would use less Panko as I hate throwing unused stuff away (especially crumbs mixed with precious parmesan), and also season the crumbs a bit with dried basil and oregano. I found after salting meat then using parmesan in crumbs and on top of chicken before oven, it was a tad salty, but that's just my taste. I only used half of the oil and must say the chicken was crispy and delicious looking after frying it as directed, but a lot of crispiness was lost after oven time as the sauce, olive oil and cheese melted through. I just 75% covered tops of chicken with sauce so bottoms were okay crispy, but nothing like it was before I put in the oven. That parmesan panko mix was just perfect for frying but I would just bake for half time then add just cheese for last half of cook time without sauce and fresh basil. The heat killed the basil so I would either add it on top after oven with the sauce, or simply put more in the sauce that I ladle on. I garuntee that would produce same effect, but keep all crisp. Respect to the man, chef John.

This was fantastic! Like other reviewers, I mixed 1/2 panko with 1/2 italian seasoned bread crumbs. I also seasoned my flour with pepper and garlic salt. I didn't measure my oil and I also added some butter and I pan fried 1-2 min/side. I sprayed my dish, then put some tomato and basil spaghetti sauce on the bottom of the dish, covered with the chicken, covered with sauce and covered with shredded italian cheese mixture and baked for 15 minutes. Everyone loved it. Kids gobbled it up and husband said to add it to the rotation!

text:
WOW...now this is Chicken Parmesan! And, while the set of instructions seems long, it really is easy to prepare and the result is nothing less than fabulous! Luckily I had some "Best Marinara Sauce Yet" from this site that I got out of the freezer and thawed for this dish. I used 6 thin sliced chicken breasts, cut back on the amount of bread crumbs and used Italian style bread crumbs vs. panko as that's what I had on hand. I did cut back on the oil since I used a non-stick pan. I opted for sliced mozzarella along with a 6 cheese Italian blend from Sargento. I love that this finishes in the oven - the chicken stays crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. My husband loved this dish, so this is how I'm going to prepare it from now on (definitely company worthy). This was perfect served with a side of angel hair pasta topped with the extra sauce, warm garlic bread and of course a nice glass of wine! Thanks Chef John for yet another great recipe!

This recipe is fantastic.  I felt like I was an Italian Chef...and should open a restaurant.  I followed it exactly.  And yes, I did use a cup of olive oil.  The pan has to have enough oil because the bread crumbs absorb the oil and the chicken will not cook properly.  I do recommend using excellent tomato sauce.  I made my own sauce (off this website).  It was outstanding.  Also I recommend using really good cheese.  I actually could grate the mozzarella cheese.  The chicken was perfect following John's instructions.  I love your videos! I plan to serve this for my mom's 80's family birthday gathering.  My sisters will be jealous!

text:
DREAM COME TRUE !!!
I always wanted to make Chicken Parmesan. I thought it would be too difficult. 
IT IS NOT !!
Recipe asks for 4 cups of Panko bread crumbs. I bought Progresso Brand Panko bread crumbs. 
There is about 3 cups in a box, there was more than enough to do all 4 breasts. 
When putting together the chicken Parmesan.... 
I used double to triple the cubed mozzarella cheese. I guess it probably depends on the size of your chicken breast. 
I did not have provolone ... So left it out. 
I used fresh grated Parmesan for the topping.  Also used more than double recipe suggestion. 
I used dried basil.

I made Marinara sauce ( Best Marinara Sauce Yet by Jackie) to go alongside the chicken Parmesan. 
It was absolutely delicious !!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I needed to make some changes, then it was DELICIOUS!
Here are just some suggestions that you may want to follow...

1. I used 1 cup of bread crumbs and still had some left over (four cups is far too much, 
2. You really only need 1/2 cup of olive oil to cook the chicken.
3. When cooking with basil it is always better to use dried basil, because fresh basil loses its flavour (sorry, flavor in U.S.) when cooked. 
4. I used Marinara sauce, and did not add any salt (there was enough salt in the sauce and bread crumbs.
5. It should be more clear in the recipe that you actually need (in total) 1 1/3 cups of sauce (1/3 cup for each piece of chicken), not 1/2 cup, as listed at the beginning (confusing).
Hope this helps,
JC

text:
I can't argue with the recipe results.  The dish was amazingly delicious.  However, there are a couple of things that don't add up with the recipe.
#1) It calls for 4 cups of bread crumbs.  This is WAY too much.  You need 1.5-2 cups tops.
#2) The ingredients list calls for 1/2 cup of tomato sauce, however, the recipe directs to put 1/3 cup of sauce on each chicken breast (4 breasts).  The math doesn't quite add up here.  Good thing I bought some extra tomato sauce.  
Again, however, the dish turned out wonderfully delicious .

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delish! I HIGHLY recommend watching Chef John's video that goes along with this recipe. I don't think mine would have come out as well if I hadn't. There are some extra tips there and it's nice to see what each step looks like. To those having trouble with it getting soggy, I think the trick is to not cover the whole thing with sauce, just spoon a little on top (again, watch the video!)
Only changes I made were to add garlic powder with the salt and pepper in step 2, and spooned a line of pesto down the middle of each piece instead fresh basil. Also I just eyeballed most of the amounts. As others have mentioned the some of  the quantities listed may be less or more than you actually need.
Served with simple noodles (with butter, olive oil, garlic, parsley) and a green salad. This is definitely a repeater!

text:
I've never seen Chicken Parmesan made with a tomato sauce or all that extra melty cheese.  The version I've made for 40 years is really just chicken coated with a parmesan bread crumb mixture and sauteed until browned (not necessarily crispy).  The drippings is the sauce.

This version was more like eggplant parmesan, which itself is sort of a lasagna.  Good, but not what I expect.

text:
It's one of our favorites. There are a LOT of breadcrumbs left after you bread the chicken however. I hate wasting food so once the chicken was transferred to the baking dish I threw the leftover breadcrumb Parmesan mixture into the pan I'd browned the chicken in with a little extra oil and browned them up so once the chicken came out of the oven I sprinkled the browned breadcrumbs on top for a crunchy coating. Very delicious texture profile

I had chicken thighs, omitted the pounding, and used seasoned Panko crumbs. I mixed the eggs in one bowl, flour in another, and lastly the cheesed seasoned Panko. Then straight into the crockpot on high (I started at 1:30) when done I heated the sauce separately and then on a nice bed of Angel Hair Pasta I spooned out the sauce per pc, layered the cheese......and viola' !! With salad and your favorite bread...mmmmmmmm

For starters, I found this recipe to be incorrect.  You only need 2 cups of Panko (otherwise, you are wasting 2 cups), and a half cup (at most, 1/3 may be closer to what is necessary) of olive oil.  The recipe could use more flavor, my recommendation is to add some itlalian seasoning and garlic to the Panko, or to the tomato sauce.  The chicken was quite tender and juicy, just not enough flavor.

None
country:
None
text:
A bit on the bland side with the plain tomato sauce. Some Italian herbs & garlic in the tomato sauce would help enormously. It's easier for me to just dredge the chicken in flour instead of sprinkling it on, then dip it in an egg wash (1 egg + 2 Tbsp water) before dredging in the seasoned crumbs. Also, you can skip the pounding entirely if you lay the chicken breast on the cutting board & slice it horizontally into 1/2" thick slices. They're smaller & easier to handle that way too.

userID:
625228
Display Name:
ROSALIE P
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews I tried this recipe, using a few suggestions. I split my chicken breasts in half and pounded them to flatten. I brushed them with whipping cream instead of egg. For the coating I used 1 1/2 cups panko mixed with 1/2 cup grated Parmesan and 1 Tbsp Italian seasoning. It didn't need extra salt. The coating was the perfect amount for 6 large breasts (12 halves). I fried them quickly using a generous amount of olive oil and butter, replenishing after each batch, but it was no where close to 1 cup of oil. I placed the cutlets in 2 buttered 8x12 dishes, topped with a large spoonful of pasta sauce and then a handful of grated of mozzarella. I used approc 3/4 C sauce and 250g cheese. I baked uncovered at 350 for 15 min. I wouldn't bake any longer - they came out perfectly. Crispy, juicy and tender. Thank you Chef John!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe for dinner last night. The only change I made was I used dried basil because I didn't have fresh basil. My family absolutely loved it! Sometimes, my kids can be very picky eaters. They were all asking for seconds! I served it with angel hair pasta. The chicken had just enough sauce and was not drowned in it and mushy. It was very crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. I had never tried the panko bread crumbs before. Very tasty! I used the seasoned kind. I think the recipe called for a little too much though, because I ended up throwing so much of it away. I also think it called for a little too much olive oil. The chicken had just enough cheese and was not overloaded. All the ingredients went well together. I would advise people to watch the video first. It really helps. The preparation was easy, but a little time consuming. I would save it for a Friday or Saturday night (for families with kids) or for a special occasion. It is definitely a keeper and I will be making it again! Thanks Chef John!

text:
Chef John has turned me into a family rock star with this recipe. It is ridiculously easy to follow and achieve delicious chicken parmesan. This was the first time I've ever made this dish and the whole family raved about it/ Then they began making plans for when I should make it again.  Your sauce application recommendation is spot on. Everyone was very pleased with the crunch.

One tweak I did was to use 2/3 canola oil in the frying pan. It's just cheaper. Second, I had forgotten to buy provolone (my favorite sandwich cheese).  Instead, I had some Beemster XO gouda on hand (A.K.A. Cheese of the Gods) and grated some on lightly before and after adding the mozzarella.   I also used a basic spicy marinara on top. It added some nice kick.  The only lament was that my wife and I miscommunicated on the fresh basil, and so we only had dried basil on top.  Even so, it was good and I could taste it, but I love fresh basil and I look forward to having it next time.  One other thing I want to try is cubed plum tomatoes on top, with a bit less sauce. It would add more texture... but it might add too much moisture. We'll see.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-07-23T21:31:45.737
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1388730
Display Name:
GEORGIACOOK1
isPro:
False

1

6
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Chef John's recipes and techniques are always great and this one is no exception, particularly if you are an experienced cook. If not, I'll make a couple of suggestions. First, olive oil has a very low burn point so be careful if you use it. I don't really think it adds much flavor to the finished dish. You can substitute a high burn point oil such as peanut or canola oil if you like. Alternatively, you can use half olive and half peanut or canola oil, heating the other oil first then adding olive oil. Again, I don't think olive oil is necessary at all and you'll ruin the dish if it burns. The only other suggestion I have is to spoon a little of the sauce in the baking dish before adding the chicken. I always make at least a double recipe and either make chicken parm subs the next day or freeze the leftover for another meal. When reheating, I always add a little fresh sauce.

text:
Once again Chef John comes through.  My 17 y.o. is a big fan of chicken parmesan and he said this was his favorite ever.  Followed the recipe exactly.  I found fresh mozzarella pearls at my grocery store that that saved me from having to cut up. some  Shredded the parm in my Vitamix because I don't have the patience for a box grater with a hard cheese like that.  I did use the grater for the provolone though.  

Served with a small side of thin spaghetti with a little of the sauce used for the chicken.  First course was a salad.  It's a little bit of work and I'm dreading cleaning up in a minute but it was worth it, and I like cooking things like this on Sundays.  I especially like Chef John's tip on using a strainer to apply the flour.  I hate the old method of dredging.  Will definitely make again.

text:
It's definitely a make again!!! It's a perfect Sunday dinner. I made it with my 11 year old and we all loved. We followed the recipe exactly as written. The only thing I would do different is that I should of drained the oil
off of the chicken before putting in the oven, or used less oil. I think that soaking up with paper towels would of be sufficient. I loved that the crispy crust didn't fall off I don't know if the secret is in letting the chicken rest for 15 min before frying or the amount of oil. It's a must make again for us! Also maybe split the chicken breast in 1/2 bec they are huge. We had them as parm chicken sandwiches the next day!

text:
Great base recipe that would be five stars if I didn't modify it to my own ingredients. I personally like regular bread crumbs so I used half regular, half panko and a whole bunch of grated parm. Instead of fresh basil I used Italian seasoning and dried basil in the crumb. Delicious.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was torn about whether to give this recipe 4 stars or 5. The flavor was FANTASTIC, and with a few minor changes (but major to the overall dish), it would CERTAINLY have deserved a 5. First off, let me just say that I made this exactly as it called for the first time. With my suggested changes, to me, it will be PERFECT next time. First of all, 4 cups of bread crumbs is ENTIRELY too much. I used 2 and STILL had quite a bit left. Secondly, the entire recipe calls for 1/2 cup of tomato sauce, but the directions say to use 1/3 cup on each of the 4 breasts...how does that work? And speaking of the sauce, it was WAY too little. I know that the recipe specifically stated that he was using less than normal, but I used a full cup and still couldn't even BARELY taste it. Also, 450 degrees was WAY too high a cooking temp. I think 400 would do.

This recipe worked well for me with one small change.  I used well less than 1/2 of the olive oil and included 2 TBs of butter for added flavor.  Other than this, it came out fine. No point in being rude to those who have been kind enough to share with the rest of us.

text:
The best Chicken Parmesan I've ever had, hands down. Crispy outside, moist and juicy inside with just the right amount of sauce and cheese....exactly as advertised. For my cheeses, I used fontina, followed by sharp provolone, and topped with parmesan (the good stuff of course!). Chef John really hit this one out of the park. Thanks for sharing your version, it's the only one I'll ever need!

I did what any home cook would do... I modified it a bit.  I added Italian bread crumbs, garlic powder, season salt, and dried oregano and basil to the panko breading.   The flavor was amazing.  I also used a half a jar of Basil spaghetti sauce to coat the bottom of the baking pan.   Somehow, my chicken was dry... no idea why!  But, the leftovers were better than the dish was fresh out of the oven!  I would make this again... Chicken Parm, you taste so good.

I made this exactly as written and am pleased to say that this is another of Chef John's truly excellent, easy-to-do recipes.  His video is SO right -- why bother making a crispy crust on the chicken if you're going to drown the whole thing in sauce?   I'll make this many, many times again just as written, not seeing a need to spice up the breadcrumbs or anything (a really good marinara would suffice).  Thanks Chef John - it was superb!

text:
This was simply amazing...I say simple because it truley was! I bought 2 thin cut chicken breast (didn't have to pound them out) and halfed the recipe. I didn't use provolone...but did use the other 2 cheeses like the recipe called for. And used both panko and seasoned bread crumbs... Built my sauce from 3 garlic cloves ...red pepper, ground oregano and black pepper with jar of my favorite tomato sauce ( roasted red pepper from classico)( cooked that first on a simmer) with angle hair pasta. Fantastic! I don't know why some people said it was bland?!?! Came out super flavorful!!

text:
35 stars!  Wife and I loved this!  She's a celiac, so I easily crushed ½ cup of GF croutons in place of the panko.  Seasoning both sides of the chicken in advance, plus letting them rest for 15 mins after dredging etc. made all the positive difference.  I'd even add more fresh basil like ¾ cup instead of ½, too.   I followed the recipe verbatim with Chef John, down to the red pepper.  This was the best Chicken Parmesan I have ever had in any restaurant, and I easily made it!   My wife was happy, I'm happy.  I could even make this as a hit at dinner party with friends.  'Really want to thank Chef John for his oh-so helpful video recipes.  He doesn't need a recording studio, he can phone them in any day...they always work great.  They're so informally easy to follow, even a husband could follow them and not screw them up.  Allrecipes is my favorite go-to cooking website and iPad app.

text:
Just made this for the first time and my husband LOVED it!  The chicken was so tender and flavorful.  I had to make a couple of adjustments but they were minor. I used a version of Monterey Jack (at least that's what it looked like) since I am overseas and they don't have provolone.  Don't have Monterey Jack either so I'm not sure what cheese this was but it was flavorful.  I also didn't have plain tomato sauce so used a jar spaghetti sauce.  Otherwise I followed the recipe exactly and it was wonderful!  I've never been a fan of chicken parmesan so I gave it 4 stars but my husband would have given it 5!  Definitely will make again.  Thank you Chef John for one more wonderful recipe.  UPDATE:  Just made it for the first time with Panko bread crumbs and real Provalone cheese!  What a difference!  I'd give it more stars if I could!  SO YUMMY!!  This is going to be a standard in our house!

text:
This dish takes a good 2 hrs from prep to table ready, it one of my favorites chicken dishes to make though. When tendering the meat (instead of 4 I used 6 ckn breast) in the freezer bag I also used a little oregano, minced garlic, & Italian or lite Caesar dressing, plus your S&P. It really helps with the flavoring. While seasoning my meat I also boiled my pasta ( thin spaghetti noodles or linguini) so I can place the pasta under my Parmesan chicken while baking. Once the timer goes off .. Whaaa Lhaaa diner is done ! Everyone in the house eats it up (4 kids & 2 adults ) even my biggest competitor & critic my husband enjoyed this dishes ! Plus theirs even leftovers for lunch or for a snack when kids get Hm from school... It's a win win !

text:
Once you get your production line going you can turn these out pretty fast & they make a really nice entree. One word of caution...be careful not to let your oil get too hot and watch them closely when they are cooking...it is very easy to burn those bread crumbs. I make these fairly often and mix it up a bit at times and top with different sauces, cheeses, a slice of ham or some bacon....pretty versatile entree.

Frozen and vacuum packed...when my two sons come to town there won't be any of them left in the freezer when they leave:-)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a dinner party. I ended cutting the chicken breast in half, since I had 8 breasts and 12 people coming. I also ended up using equal parts panko, regular bread crumb and Italian breadcrumbs, as that is what I had in the house(2c. each, WAY too much), with double the Parmesan cheese and a pinch of garlic powder. I used regular shredded mozzarella and sliced provolone since it was all I could find and it worked fine. I would suggest to anyone making this to put the basil under the cheese, so that it doesn't shrivel and brown up. And use sweet basil, it's the best kind. Anyhow, this was a big hit and the smell even enticed my vegetarian mother to have some and she can't stop raving about it. Also, my brothers fought over the left overs (they only do that for one other meal), so I know it's good then. Definitely going to be a keeper.

text:
Great recipe.  Chicken is very flavorful and moist.  Added a little garlic powder to season the chicken.  Only used 2 cups of panko bread crumbs with 1/2 cup of shredded parmesan and it was perfect proportions.  2 more cups of panko would of been a waste.  Instead of using tomato sauce, I used marinara sauce.  Made lots of the marinara sauce so that I could serve this along with a bed of spaghetti with sauce.   Liked the idea of sifting the flour over the chicken.  Will use that tip on future recipes!  I ended up with 6 chicken cutlets. The breasts spread out when pounding, so, I cut them in half.  Then, I also had two boneless skinless thighs as that is what my BF prefers.  Turned out fabulous!

text:
I liked the method for cooking this recipe. The chicken came out very nicely - crunchy on the outside and softer on the inside. I had my one at 350 for something else and left it there so the chicken cooked at 350 for 20 mins and still came out perfect. I hammered some of the pieces thinner, but others were on the thin side already so I left them alone. All seemed to be good. I did not have fresh basil and I did not have provolone cheese...which I think would explain why it tasted a bit bland to me (even with Italian Seasoned bread crumbs). Looking forward to trying it again with those additions. I can't remember if this was in the original directions, but I did include some freshly grated parm cheese in my bread crumbs and served this over pasta.

text:
My husband's new favorite!  My kids love this!  It is important that you use PANKO breadcrumbs, it makes it crispier and therefore it will not get soggy.  I use Bove's marinara sauce (from VT).  I omit the salt because there is salt in the panko and cheese and I found it too overwhelming.  I also use chicken tenderloins for the kids like because they are smaller (and easier to flatten out and much shorter fry time), but chicken breasts for my husband.   Delish.  Every time.

text:
Since I had never made a chicken parmesan before, I was a little hesitant but the reviews helped me make the decision to make it.  I ran out of Panko bread crumbs, so I improvised with some Melba toast that I ran thru the processor for a few seconds.  I added Italian seasoning to the crums as well as to the tomato sauce (basil, Italian Seasoning, and garlic powder) which definitely helped the overall flavor.  I liked the use of tomato sauce instead of spaghetti sauce due to the amount sauce that would have been leftover.  I made it for two and it was wonderful.  I served it with a tomato-pesto farfalle pasta dish and it was great!

text:
Awesome!  Beautiful Presentation and wonderful flavors.  I have just began cooking after 25 years; I used to be a simple meat and potato comfort food cook.  My husband has been retired for many years and has been the cook of the family; mostly he cooks gourmet and everything he makes is delicious. Since I have retired I have tried many recipes from this site as well as multiple cook books and magazines.  I have finally a bravo for this recipe.  Thank you.  I did change it up a bit.  I increased all cheese amounts by at least 1/3 and doubled the sauce amount.  In place of provolone I used Asioga cheese.  I used 2/3 of a jar of Ragu  Spaghetti Sauce with garlic and onion. I used the extra 1/3 jar of Ragu to drizzle over Garlic Penne Pasta.  I generously sprinkled parmesan cheese over all.  Yummy and beautiful!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-02-11T20:36:23.517
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
3688261
Display Name:
slackgeek
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
22
favoritesCount:
180
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so good! I have never made chicken parmesan before, so I was looking for a recipe to follow loosely because I had no idea what I was doing. I still followed it pretty accurately.

I did half the recipe. I bought a package of 2 chicken breasts; they still had the tenderloin and weighed 1.45lb. They were huge! I cut off the tenderloin, and cut the breasts in half width-wise. I then pounded them, except the tenderloin. It still ended up making so much.

I mixed salt and pepper into the flour, and a little onion and garlic powder. I then sprinkled the flour mixture to coat each side of the breasts. I also added to the breadcrumbs; garlic and onion powder, dried basil, parsley, and oregano, plus the parmesan cheese. I mixed it all together, dipped each piece of chicken in the egg, and generously coated them with breadcrumbs. I let them sit in the fridge for 20 minutes.

I pan fried them in butter and a little olive oil; 3-5 minutes per side, until they were nicely browned, then transferred them to 13x9 casserole dish, which I greased lightly. I used marinara sauce instead of tomato sauce. I topped with the cheese that I had: monterey jack, gruyere, and fresh parmesan. I did not have fresh basil because it's not in season yet, so I sprinkled a little dried basil, then drizzled with olive oil.

I needed them to cook more slowly, so I dropped the temperature to 375 and baked them for 45 minutes, until the cheese was nicely browned, and served over spaghetti.

Delicious!!

text:
Like others i noticed the video and recipe are different. I liked the text recipe so I tried that and loved it. Made the following changes based on user reviews: Make sure to generously salt and pepper the chicken - used 1/2 panko and 1/2 italian bread crumbs along with the parmesan and added garlic powder to the mix. Used Barilla Garlic spag sauce instead of tomato sauce. Loved the added garlic flavor. Everything else was to the written ingredients. Agree, you don't need 4 cups of bread crumbs - you could half it to save on cost. My boyfriend said it was one of the best meals I have ever served him. Def a keeper!

Best Chicken Parmesan ever and will look no further.  Thank you Chef John! Awesome!

text:
This was easy to make and tasted great. We like bold flavor so I seasoned everything; the meat as I pounded it, the egg mixture, and the panko/bread crumbs. I put 1/3 cup spagetti sauce on top of each meat peice and no issues with soggy crust. Husband really liked it. I did use dark meat as the bag I thought had breast meat was actually dark meat and that worked out just fine. I baked it at 350 so as not to overcook the pounded thin meat and I would do that again.  Thanks for sharing another great recipe.

text:
I'm not sure what happened but this is the most bland chicken parm I've ever made. When you cut into it, the breading you took so long to prepare will slide right off with the sauce and rubbery cheese. Next time I will marinate the chicken beforehand, season the breadcrumbs better, bake breaded chicken before adding the sauce (much more sauce!!), use no provolone, then pop it back in the oven to melt, *then* add the fresh basil.

text:
I believe that the amount of oil is correct for pan frying the chicken.  If you place the chicken on a plate with paper towels prior to placing them in the baking dish it cuts back on extra oil if it bothers you. If you use less oil, the sides of the chicken won’t pan fry.  I used spaghetti sauce as the “prepared tomato sauce.”  I agree with other reviewers that you could add flavor by using Italian bread crumbs instead of plain. It is a great Chicken Parmesan recipe.  Thank you for sharing!

text:
Great recipe, but I cant make anything without a little tweaking.  I season the flower with onion and garlic powder.  Add grated parmesan, shredded mozzarella to the sauce, but still use chunks of mozzarella on top.  About 4-5 mozzarella sticks cut with scissors to about 1/3 in slices.  The chicken is done once the mozzarella is starting to bubble and brown.

text:
This was my first time making chicken Parm. I made it mostly as written, and it was delicious. I added some Italian seasoned bread crumbs to the panko and parm, omitted the mozzarella, and used slices of provolone (that's how I've always had it when others made it) I started with 1/2 cup olive oil after reading another review, but ended adding the rest half way through, for the last two chicken breasts. Served it over tagliatelli. Please read recipes carefully. There are others criticizing this for measurements that aren't actually written.

text:
There is no "4.5" star option, so 5 it is. Having explained all that (and I just know you were waiting with bated breath for that info), this is a fantastic recipe (as is everything I have ever tried of Chef John's)! Please note that he made a 'new & improved' version of this dish, and it, he uses regular breadcrumbs, instead of the panko that he uses in this recipe. Those panko breadcrumbs are the only reason why I can't give this a full 5 stars. I am definitely making this again & again & again, but going forward, I will be using regular bread crumbs. (His other version uses plain crumbs, but I bet the Italian would be fabulous, too!) The biggest thing, y'all... seriously... *if at all possible, use the FRESH mozzarella and the FRESH basil.* It truly makes this dish. And follow Chef John!! You won't regret it. He's my absolute favorite around here - He makes FUN videos, and INCREDIBLE food. Thanks, Chef John!!

text:
My family loved it! I had a little more chicken than it called for, so I added about a half of a cup of Italian breadcrumbs to my cup of panko. I used one egg with some milk instead of two eggs, and I didn't have any provolone or fresh mozzarella, so I used sliced mozzarella. I did add Parmesan on the top and the olive oil, too. I deep-fried my chicken in a FryDaddy (it already had oil), which worked like a charm to brown it with less splatter. I know, I know: I changed things. But I baked after adding sauce and cheese, and while dinner tonight was great, I'm equally excited to have the leftovers tomorrow. I'd make this again!

text:
I didn't have mozzarella, so I used muenster instead, with provolone and parmesan. TIP: Don't line the pan with aluminum foil. Also I need to cut the cooking time by 5-10 minutes in the oven. The cheese bubbled over and went under the chicken - and glued it to the foil! I had to rip the pieces off the foil, and pick out pieces from the overcooked (but deliciosus) cheese crust!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good! I didn't change much of the recipe. I used 8 thin chicken cutlets and the recipe's measurements were spot on. I preheated the oven when I started frying the cutlets, not at the start of preparing the cutlets. Remember, they have to sit for 15 minutes. I only sprinkled one side of the cutlets with salt and pepper, otherwise it would have been too salty. I used dried basil and it was fine. (One time, by accident, I put  1/2 c. of parm with 1 cup of flour. I still dipped it in 1 c. of bread crumbs and 1/2 c. of parm. Pretty good!)  I covered it and then uncovered for the last ten minutes. It was in the oven for 20 minutes. I've used provolone when I had it and shredded parm when I didn't have provolone on hand. Both will work, but I prefer the provolone. Wonderful!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I too used two chicken breast and the full sauce recipe. I butterflied each breast, ending up with four pieces. I seasoned each breast with lemon pepper seasoning and also seasoned the flour and Panko mixture the same. After browning the chicken, I placed them in a baking dish, covered them tomato sauce and cheese and baked until the cheese was browned. 
I served the chicken with pasta and more tomato sauce. It’s a keeper.

I used seasoned panko, I didn't measure my oil but made sure there was lots in the bottom of the pan and used mostly vegetable oil with just a bit of olive oil for flavor. I had angel hair pasta and used almost a whole bottle of garlic spaghetti sauce.

text:
This is going to become a staple in our house!
I had to modify the recipe for a Gluten-free diet in the family.
Substitutions included:
GF flour (King Arthur's)
GF cornflake crumbs for the Panko  I also used a GF Coating mix to add seasoning.
GF jarred Marinara sauce instead of tomato sauce
Dried Herbs de Provence in place of the Basil
Shreaded Colby Jack instead of Mozzarella (I wasn't going to the store just for cheese, lol)

This turned out FANTASTIC.  I will be making it again.  (I'll try to have mozzarella on hand, OK?)

Wonderful recipe. I’m not sure why all the suggestions for drastic changes. I literally followed this to the letter except for two things simply because of items I had. I used Rao’s tomato basil jarred sauce and I used Monterey Jack in place of the provolone. It’s CHICKEN parmesan. The star should be the chicken. Mine turned out perfectly cooked (I timed everything according to the recipe) and very moist and tender. Definitely going to take this one down to the firehouse when I’m on shift. It’s a keeper. Paired it with the basil parmesan orzo that popped up when I did a search for most popular chicken parmesan.

Made as directed except provolone (we didn't have any). I did watch the video and appreciate smaller tips (season the chicken not the breadcrumbs, allow breading to dry before 'frying'). 

I did brown in my cast iron skillet,  then drained remaining oil before baking in oven. My pan was already so hot I could easily reduce temperature to 400 and cook for a few less minutes with same end result. 

Very nice crunch and flavor combos. We served with a salad and enjoyed very much- will make again.

country:
None
text:
I pretty much followed this to a T and it turned out superb. Using an entire cup of olive oil seemed pretty overkill though—if you want to save money, just eyeball the amount and brown 1-2 breasts at a time on the skillet. When adding the cheese, I grated equal amounts provolone and mozzarella, then added a decent amount of basil and mixed it all into a bowl until it looked something akin to cilantro rice LOL. The one thing I really experimented with was adding the basil/cheese layer first, then the tomato sauce, then sprinkled parmesan on top! Popped it in the oven for about 10 mins and it was perfect :)

text:
We made six servings. We did regular bread crumbs instead of panko by preference. We also used mushroom spaghetti sauce with a little Merlot in it and layered the pan with some sauce then the chicken then covered it in sauce and covered the pan in a shredded mixture of parmesan, mozzarella and provolone all over then cooked according to the recipe and added more of the cheese mixture and made with spaghetti noodles. We also put the breaded chicken right into the hot oil instead of letting it sit for 15 minutes like the recipe said to after dipping in the eggs then bread crumb and cheese mixture. Otherwise, we followed the recipe and it was really good. We also covered the noodles in the leftover cooked sauce on the noodles and added some cooked and uncooked cheese.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great option for dinner, only changed 1 thing. Instead of putting the sauce and cheese on then cooking for 15-20 mins. Put the chicken in the oven first for 12-15 mins by it self, take it out and put your sauce and cheese on and put it back in for the remaining time. I usually go with 15 and an extra 5.

the cheese gets a little to overcooked if it's in for the whole duration, and if you just put the sauce on first you'll dry it out. My way has worked great multiple times.

country:

text:
I have to say one thing before anything else... unless you are buying pygmy chicken breasts, focus on getting  1/3 pound chicken breast per person and you'll be fine.  And I say this with the disclaimer that I eat a LOT. Problem is, you need to fit the pounded breasts into a standard baking dish, and I had to use a 9" x 13" AND an 8" x 8" to get this done. Was it worth it?

Oh, HELLZ yeah!

This is a simple, great recipe. What I come to Allrecipes for, and what I usually get here. The recipe as it stands is almost certainly fine on every level. I changed only a couple things and I think it came out better because of it. I could be wrong... Let's see.

First things first, had I known this would be so good, I would have planned on using two 9" x 13" baking pans (Pyrex pans) and just run forward like a drunken reveler heading to Mardi Gras. Perhaps the faux pas was my own in not putting 2 + 2 together on my own in the first place (4 chicken breast halves , a total of 1/2 cup tomato sauce and you are to place about 1/3 cup on each breast: this isn't rocket science. Then there's the flour... "Or more if needed" should always make you suspect the involvement of wine in the posting of a recipe, but if it doesn't, weigh it against the overall amount of the specific food it's supposed to cover. 4 breasts that need flour for dunkin' comes out to "Or more if needed"! Start with a 1/4 cup of flour. Flour is cheap.) 

Second things second; you're using eggs and bread crumbs. Have you EVER

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm 16 and this is the first dish I've prepared for my family where everyone was like "mmmmm" and only struggled to swallow it because it was too hot and delicious to wait for it to cool down. It tasted juicy and tender and like pizza honestly, but better. It's light enough you can feel good afterwards but heavy enough you feel satisfied. The ingredients are not what my family is used to using since many of them are not found commonly where we are from so we had to buy almost everything for the dish. I didn't add more oil on top of it because it seemed a bit much and it turned out perfect with a little bit of oil on the bottom of the pan. I cooked it in a casserole dish with the lid on first and then took the lid off and turned the oven on broil to let the cheese brown since it wasn't doing it on bake. It cooked way more than we expected so not everyone was able to finish a whole chicken but that's okay because they liked it soo much they wouldn't let anyone else eat it and wanted to save it for tomorrow. Hahaha. Overall the dish was scrumptious! Next time I'm adding three slices of mozzarella instead of 1 and adding paprika to the breading. We also couldn't find provolone in the store (it must of been out) and made it without it but I didn't even notice anything was missing. I may add it next time if I can find it and make a salad or some "angel hair pasta" like some of the people in the comments here which will be also new. I'm glad I got to enjoy cooking this with my famil

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great kid-friendly meal!  I used chicken tenderloins so I didn’t need to pound them - (my supermarkets also offer thin sliced breasts which would work well) - anything to avoid an extra step!  I did do half butter/half olive oil, generously.  This recipe calls for the chicken to almost be fried versus sautéed- so if you’re going healthy, go for the sauté. If you’re going to impress, fry these up!  Either way, works. Some commented on the “blandness” - I would agree, but kids love bland!  You can jazz up half of the dish with extra herbs for the grown ups, and keep it as is for the kids.  This recipe works - method is the best I’ve come along on in a long time.

text:
I love chicken parm and am always trying out new recipes for this dish. This one was a good find! Admittedly, I didn't have the fresh ingredients (recipe calls for fresh basil and mozzarella cheese, but I used dried basil and shredded mozz), which I'm sure would've made this dish even better. I also didn't have the provolone cheese, so the dish was lacking another cheese. I didn't have panko bread crumbs, but found that plain bread crumbs I had in the pantry did just as well. Overall, a pretty decent dish that was quick and easy to prepare!

text:
Really straight forward, great taste, and nice and crispy. I added some Italian seasoning and garlic powder to the panko and parmesan cheese mixture and only had to cook the chicken in the frying pan for about 30 seconds each side to avoid from burning. Other than that, I basically followed the recipe as is and it was awesome.

Small correction to above, I skipped the provolone because I missed in on the ingredients list and didn't buy it. I also cooked it on a wire rack on a cooking sheet. I find that makes things even crispier. Still love it!

text:
Great recipe! It's delicious as is, so no need to make any changes. I have also tried it without frying the chicken first (I just baked it) because of special dietary requests. It was just as good that way, in my opinion. When skipping the frying, I omitted the olive oil and flour, and I waited to add the cheese until after the chicken had cooked. This is definitely a keeper!

text:
easy to make and sooooooo good with the right ingredients. Buy a nice piece of bread and toast it mmmm. Get a good kind of parm cheese and provolone. 

if you make your own tomato sauce, this is another excuse to make more :)

You definitely should use thermometer when frying the chicken, and a deep skillet. Will be a bummer if you end up over cooking or under cooking the chicken, so just buy a thermometer.

I would definitely make again.  My family loved it.  The 1 cup olive oil was daunting, but once in the pan, it really doesn't look like too much.  I typically don't use a cup of oil, so that is probably why I don't normally get a good crisp.  My only substitution was because Giant Eagle was out of fresh basil for the 2nd week in a row.  I mixed a basil paste with the some fresh parsley and it tasted fantastic.  Chicken was super moist too.

text:
First time making chicken parmesan and this recipe was literally perfect! I was shocked.

Changes: 
-Used sunflower oil because I was out of olive oil
-Let the chicken sit for 15 minutes, then flipped it and added a bit more flour to any areas that were still sticky, and let it sit another 5 minutes. 
-Used a regular bag of "Italian blend" shredded cheese vs fresh mozz and provolone. 
-Used "Italian Style" breadcrumbs
-Added a few sprinkles of seasoning salt in addition to sea salt and black pepper

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-10-11T22:36:29.933

None
text:
Great recipe ..... with a modification or 2.  I'm just wondering how a lot of people made this "exactly as written" and managed to put 1/3 cup tomato sauce on each of 4 chicken breasts when they started  out with only 1/2 cup of sauce.  What's the magic way to get sauce to multiply itself?  lol  Add some salt and pepper to the breading so it's not blah tasting.  If you want the crust to stay crispy, avoid putting sauce on the chicken when you put it in the oven.  Fry the chicken a bit longer and when putting it in the oven, just put the sauce around it and not over it.

text:
This recipe is fantastic!  It is worth the extra steps (waiting 15 mins. Each after sifted flour and crumbs setting) and the expense of sautéing in olive oil.  1 cup, wow!  The coating  was crispy and almost pumped up while the chicken was moist and juicy.  Just yummy and I had two pieces!  I would totally serve this to company and I don’t say that lightly. It was that good.  Use fresh tomato sauce and fresh basil.  Don’t skimp, it’s what makes this SO good.  The only thing I’d add is Italian seasoning to the crumb mixture because I had plain Panko crumbs as the recipe did not specify plain or flavored and I think it would have been enhanced with the addition of the herbs. Subtle but important.  I bought good mozzarella for the top as well and it was worth it.  Great recipe!

text:
This was one of my best meals. At least that's what my boyfriend and I thought. I buy huge chicken breasts from Sams club. I pounded them with a regular hammer in a plastic bag because that's all I have and it worked to even them out. Then I cut them in half.  Since I didn't want my sauce to taste like spaghetti sauce in a jar (because that's what it was) I fried some onions and garlic in oil, then added white wine and the sauce and more spices. Next time I should add more than one clove of garlic.  Simmered it for an hour or so and it was great.  I also didn't have the correct cheeses so I just used what I had including some older cheddar cheese that I just cut off the mold and it tasted a little sharper. I love sauce and was tempted to use a lot of it. But I followed the recipe as Chef John said don't drowned out the chicken. The crunch was awesome and my fresh basil from the garden was awesome.

city:

country:

text:
Just a few adjustments - I don't pound the chicken breasts, I either use thin cut breasts or halve regular breasts the long way; they will cook quickly and are moist.  I mixed half panko, half Herb & Garlic bread crumbs; added 4-5 minced garlic cloves and fresh ground pepper to the beaten egg. I don't let them sit 15 minutes after breading the chicken breasts, and I heat the skillet with just 2-3 tablespoons of olive oil before pan frying. I cover the bottom of glass baking pans with some sauce (only one pan needed for 2-3 people, used two pans for 4-6 people and adjust recipe amounts) and place only a single layer of the pan fried chicken breasts on the sauce. Layered imported provolone, then added sliced  smoked fresh mozzarella instead of regular,  for awesome added flavor. Added more sauce, then the chopped basil and sprinkled with the parmesan cheese before baking as directed.  This is now my go-to chicken parm recipe!

Nice recipe, but I used homemade day old Italian bread crumbed with dried herbs , Parmesan , and toasted a bit in the oven. then cooled. Panko is nice for frying Japanese and Asian style seafood dishes but I prefer a more traditional Italian American breadcrumb since Chicken Parmesan is an Italian American dish. Chef John is great but I'll go with the old school style.

userID:
23007248
Display Name:
Joseph Hilger
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
36
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4798312.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A wonder of Wonders!!  My Daughter, Wife and even my 13 yr old granddaughter raved about this dish.

Firstly, before anything else you do.... Watch the vid! Chef John has some cost-effective tips on flouring your chicken. As well as seasoning the chicken, instead of the flour, eggs, and panko.  You will never do it any other way, again.

Two things I changed was to use my wife's spaghetti sauce. Of course... The other was to use Italian Seasoning instead of fresh basil, which was not at hand.

The most important aspect of building the layers, per Chef John, was using the sauce sparingly. Keeping it away from the edges, about 1/2", so they crisp up in the oven providing that delicious crunch factor.
  
Chef John recommended the mozzarella and provolone be cut to about  3/8"pieces.  Believe me, it's worth the extra effort.  With all the cheeses, I made sure to keep them on top of the sauce bed and away from the edges, as well. I made sure to remember the sprinkling of olive oil over the cheese.

One last thing I did. Not knowing just how much the chicken got done while frying, I checked them at 12 mins and found that was sufficient time to read 165 degrees F. 

I hope these tips will produce the same savory and delicious results as was enjoyed by my family. We WILL be making this again and again...
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-09-09T23:37:03.637

text:
I thought this recipe was exceptional. I really enjoyed it a lot and it completely sufficed my craving for chicken parmesan. However, I did just a few things different- not a lot- that the recipe didn't call for. Such as doing slices of the provolone instead of grated. And I didn't use Panko brand crumbs, just generic crumbs and they worked just fine. I was a huge fan of the sauce recommended and put more than the recipe called for on each chicken and it turned out great. I didn't do full chicken breasts, either, cutting them into cutlets, which works just as great.

country:
None
text:
Hi Chef John - Chef Jack here. I thought I would give this recipe a try. I must say it was absolutely delicious. Everyone commented how good it was. The only thing I changed is I browned the crusted chicken longer, as a professional chef  (I trained at CIS) and at 450 degrees chicken breasts pounded out to 1/2 inch  and baked for 20 minutes will be over cooked. I browned them in the fry pan until they were  almost done then I put all of the delicious cheeses on top and the Basil, and popped them in the broiler until the cheeses melted..  The chicken came out perfect. Thanks for sharing this outstanding recipe.

The chicken, as the recipe listed above, was a bit bland.

userID:
22590384
Display Name:
Daniel
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5256333.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out beautifully! For the sauce- since I already had it on hand, I used a can of fire roasted diced tomatoes w/ green chiles, and just picked the chili pieces out. It didn't take long at all, and later I omitted the red chili pepper flakes. To that I added 4 minced cloves of garlic, on med-high heat, crushing it all down and then reducing the heat to add a can of tomato paste and a can of tomato sauce. It's very important to not over-fry the chicken. I accidentally filleted (and then pounded) my chicken a little too thin, so I only needed about a minute or 1:15 on each side, and then 15 minutes in the oven. Only thing I would change next time: to let the it cool after baking, I would place it on a rack or on paper towels instead of letting it sit in the baking dish, because some of the residual frying oil saturated the bottoms and impacted the wonderful crunchiness of the panko.

text:
I made this for dinner last night and both hubby and I loved it. It was tender and juicy on the inside and crunchy with some spice on the outside. I served it with a side of pasta in the same red sauce and a salad, and it was one of the best meals I've cooked in awhile. We will definitely be having this again.  

I had 3 small changes: 1) I did not have fresh basil so I used Italian seasoning instead and it was fine. 2) I used an arrabbiata sauce to make it more spicy instead of the red pepper flakes mentioned in the video. 3) I used only half of the olive oil it called for and the frying part worked just fine.  I also used only reduced-fat cheeses to lower the fat content a little.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just be careful frying with olive oil!! It has a really low burning point, which I learned after almost torching our house down. The fry-pan was just a ball of flames, luckily we have a fire extinguisher and I was able to get it onto the back deck and douse the fire. Next time I'll use vegetable oil. :(  Update: FWIW, after the fire fiasco, I just baked the chicken 5 mins per side at 450, then topped it with the cheese/sauce, and baked for another 15, broiled on low for 3, and it was really, really good.

cchisham

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe took me longer to make than I had initially planned, but it was delicious. My 8 year old picky eater told me she loved it when I asked her if she liked it. I did not follow the recipe exactly but took a few tips from others...1) I did not use grated provolone because I could not find any at the grocery store I was at and was not that concerned to travel to another store that would have probably carried. 2) I used some of the tomato sauce on the bottom of the pan not oil when baking. 3) I used 1/2 cup of panko and 1/2 cup of Italian seasoned bread crumbs. 4) I covered with foil and baked without the mozzarella cheese and basil, for 20 min then removed foil added basil and cheese and baked for 10 min. Chicken was delicious and moist served with spaghetti noodles w/ same sauce, salad and garlic bread. Will definitely be making again. I like the suggestion to prepare chicken and freeze to cut down on prep time will have to try that.

text:
I made this for dinner and it was phenomenal.  I did make a couple.of changes.  First, I used 1/2 cup each of seasoned bread crumbs, panko bread crumbs and grated Parmesan cheese.  I also put dried oregano and basil into the flour.  I pan-fried the chicken in a mixture of  garlic oil and butter-probably about 2 Tbsp of each, then into the oven to finish baking.  I served it with a romaine salad, garlic bread and linguini with brown butter sauce.   I will definitely be making this again!

I used Prego Roasted Garlic & Herb sauce and added 1 tablespoon of red pepper flakes to really spice it up. Also, I substituted Cache Valley Creamery shredded six-cheese Italian blend in place of the individual cheeses. I added half the fresh basil to the chicken at the start of baking, then added the remaining half of the basil three minutes before baking was finished. Phenomenal recipe and I'll definitely make it again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Key to recipe is not to overdue the sauce.  Too much gets  soggy.  Too little gets dry.  Leave border of chicken around sauce.  Also, pounding chicken down thin to recipe ensures even cooking and sauce and cheese staying on chicken and not overflowing.  Some other recipes pan fry the breaded chicken before the final oven bake with sauce and cheese.  This can work also to reduce soggy sauce and maintain crisp crunch.

text:
Really tasty!

I made this an d it was very delicious.  I cut the recipe in half because I made two instead of four, but it worked out just fine.

The only difference is that I still dredged the chicken a little because just dusting the top did not give enough cover.

I also beat the egg in a blender which seemed to made it lighter somehow.  This was for sure a hit at our house!

BakingBot

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2464.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great dish for company.  The end result has a fairly crispy outside and is juicy and delicious inside.  I cooked on a slitted roasting pan so the bread crumbs could get crisp (instead of mushy from sitting in the chicken juice).  Added Italian seasoning an put the fresh basil on at the end so it wouldn't burn.  The amount of bread crumbs is excessive - you likely only need half of what is called for; you do need the full 1 cup of olive oil for browning.  I omitted the provolone cheese.  The recipe is a bit labor intensive, but turns out very tasty. I used 5 full skinless chicken breasts.

I skipped the flour part and didn't use Provolone, just parm. Now I don't know if it's due to the oven being too hot or it was in there too long - I did 15 minutes instead of 20, thankfully - but I found it dried out the chicken and the tomato sauce and mozzarella cheese were non-existent! Mine did NOT come out looking like it does in photos! IF I were to make again, I'd put the oven lower - maybe 400. Surprisingly, it wasn't bad but as I mentioned, a tad dry.

region:

country:
None
text:
I make this recipe all the time for my boyfriend and I and we can't get enough of it! The first time I made this I copied the recipe to a T and it was sooooo delicious! I now make very minor changes, though it's great the way it is in the recipe .

* I now add more mozzarella cheese and fresh basil and it's even more tasty

*Do not skimp out and use cheap/bland sauce. You will be disappointed. I buy extra sauce because I always top the chicken parm over pasta 

*Do not prep as much bread crumb mixture as suggested. I had a lot left over and had to throw it out. You can always make more if you need more, but you can't really save what was unused

5

I’m sort of new to cooking and this recipe was easy and delicious! I did make a few changes to the receipe because I love FLAVOR. I used garlic infused olive oil. Based on other reviews I used half seasoned panko bread crumbs and half plain. I seasoned my chicken with salt, garlic pepper, onion powder, and garlic powder. Instead of using mozzerella and provolone I used an Italian cheese blend from Kraft (the blend contained both). I still used grated parmesan. I cooked 4 servings and I didn’t need 4 cups of bread crumbs. 2-3 would’ve been enough. Lastly, i sprinkled an Italian seasoning mix on top of the cheese before placing it in the oven. My husband is a picky eater but HE LOVED IT!

text:
This was very tasty.  I took the advice of one reviewer and skipped the flour/egg steps and just brushed on heavy whipping cream and dipped in Panko/parmesan mixture.  It still had a nice crunchy coating.  Also, it is listed to use 1 cup of olive oil, which seemed excessive to me.  I used about a 1/4 cup and I actually made 6 large chicken breasts.  I used a homemade marinara sauce instead of the tomato sauce.  It was delicious and I will definitely make again.

text:
I know Chef John is the king of cooking so I make it with just a couple small changes. Number one, a little less Olive oil and careful patting of the browned breaded chicken breast with a paper towel. Otherwise I feel like I can taste the oil. Two, more sauce. BUT, I always cook it to completion with just the sauce in the recipe and add some of my own upon serving. Make sure you are using chicken breasts of about 3/4 pounds each and 20 min is perfect. If smaller or thinner cut the time down. This is the best chicken parmesan I have ever had!

text:
Great recipe, fundamentally!  As always, I looked over several of the reviews, and RebeccaD was "dead on!" You shouldn't need the amount of breadcrumbs called for, and I wouldn't use the amount of olive oil called for (too much), and you will need more sauce than is listed in the ingredients list (it doesn't match up with the cooking instructions). So, there are some quantity errors... no biggie. We've figured that out and this is a darned good recipe! Keeper!

text:
Great recipe, however I made a few changes.. I had time so I marinated the chicken with Italian herbs. I dipped the chicken in ranch dressing instead of egg as I've found it to be more flavorful. I used Italian panko bread crumbs and only used maybe 2 tbsp of olive oil for frying. I had fresh parsley on hand so sprinkled that on the chicken and cheese. This recipe will work with vodka sauce and leftovers are even better the next day!

text:
These turned out great.  I did follow some of the other suggestions to use about 1 cup of breadcrumbs (I used italian seasoned breadcrumbs), mixed with 1/4 cup of grated mixed cheese. My family loved it! Amazing! I agree with others here - you don't need as many breadcrumbs as it calls for; maybe half that much. country:
None
text:
Loved the panko and Parmesan cheese combo. I only used two chicken breasts (split one) and used one cup panko and 1/4 cup Parmesan cheese and that was plenty.  I also fried the chicken 5-6 mins per side and then sprinkled with shredded mozzarella, covered fry pan until that melted and served with a side of spaghetti and marinara. My preference is to not cover the crispy fried chicken with marinara and make it soggy.  The result was a wonderful, crispy Chicken Parmesan!

text:
Loved this!!! Made some tweaks based on reading reviews. I didn't need nearly as many breadcrumbs as what was called out, I probably used 1 cup at most. I also added salt, oregano, parsley, thyme, cilantro, and sage to both the Panko mix and the tomato sauce. It turned out fantastic, and I kept the extra sauce so anyone could add more to it if they wanted more on their chicken. The chicken turned out SO juicy and crispy. Awesome!

country:
None
text:
Did tweek recipe a bit. Used 5 bagged frozen chicken breasts thawed (they run smaller and are already flattened which saved time), garlic salt, only 1 cup of Italian seasoned breadcrumbs was necessary to bread this those 5 pieces.  In place of the tomato sauce and fresh basil, used the entire jar of Bertolli tomato & basil 24 oz sauce, shredded mozzarella and grated Parmesan, no provolone available so it was omitted. Roasted some asparagus during the last 15 min of baking and served with the chicken over angel hair.  (Note-Would probably have needed more breadcrumbs as well as sauce if fresh chicken breasts were used).   The whole meal was prepared and ready in under an hour!

userID:
12830724
Display Name:
fites17
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
289
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is much better than restaurant chicken parm. It's our favorite recipe that we've ever found online. We now search Chef John recipes on here for most meals.

We've adjusted the recipe to make it gluten-free only by using gluten-free bread crumbs, but no one ever notices the difference. It's still delicious, and the leftovers might be even better. This also freezes very well.

If you want to save time or make it a little less labor-intensive and messy, we do the following:
1. Buy chicken breasts that have already been pre-sliced (so one normal chicken breast becomes 3 or 4; look for "thin chicken breast at the supermarket.) It saves the mess of having to hammer them flat.
2. We normally skip the part of adding flour (instead just put the chicken directly into the eggs and then the bread crumbs). If you try this, too, let the chicken sit longer than the recipe suggests for the bread crumbs to stick (more like 20-30 minutes than 15).
3. We use shredded mozzarella instead of the cubed fresh mozzarella suggested.

Also, quick tip: keep in mind that you're only cooking the chicken in the oil for the bread crumbs, so watch them closely (it's easy for them to get a little burnt; made that mistake the first few times).

Thanks, Chef John. This is our favorite meal and always a great pick-me-up.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-03-13T06:47:18.09
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Excellent!!!!  and everyone enjoyed even my fussy grandchild. 
But I have one concern I find the 4 cups of Panko is a bit of a waste. I have to throw a lot out. Especially when I double the recipe and freeze the chicken. It is greater straight from the oven but also great from the frozen state. Secret thaw in fridge overnight and less time in oven for warmup.  
That avoids drying out the chicken.  I usually cover to warm up then uncover for the last 5 minutes. . Warm up at 350 for about 20 minutes

text:
Very ez pz to make. I didn't change anything other than make my own tomato sauce. Very easy to do. 28oz can of crushed tomatoes. Heat up a bit of oil in the pan, fry up some garlic for about 45 seconds, dump in that can of tomatoes and season with salt pepper and Italian seasoning. I also add a few fresh basil leaves. Simmer for about 10 minutes reducing heat to almost low about halfway thru. Very yummy chicken parm

text:
The only reason I gave it a four was because I haven't eaten any, but it smells FAB U LOUS!

I am making this for a friend so that she has some meals in the freezer.

I followed the recipe, as best I could, with what I have at home.

Love the way to do the flour, that was awesome, used home dried oregano from my garden, didn't use quite as much parmesan because I didn't have enough.  Used home grown tomatoes, that I had frozen, and used an immersion blender to smooth them out.  For cheese, I had mozzarella/provolone blend.  Didn't measure out the flour, or the panko, just eyeballed it.

I can't wait to make this for my family and I have added to my recipe box.

Thank you for the great recipe!

country:
None
text:
I made the dish following the instructions carefully.   I loved the crispy crust but chicken was overdone.  When I make it again, I will make the following changes:
Fry the chicken breasts on medium high for 5 min per side to brown.  When you pound the breasts to 1/2 inch, they don't need to be cooked too long.
Heat the tomato sauce till bubbly.
Do not bake it, put sauce and final cheeses on, remove from heat, cover until cheese is melted.

text:
Made as prepared and it was a tad bland.  Second try, mixed 1/2 planko and 1/2 Italian seasoned bread crumbs for the coating.  Also, cut pounded chicken /breasts into smaller pieces, more manageable.  Let sit after breading for half hour on waxed paper before frying.  Fries up better.  Used sliced provolone instead of shredded.  Also, used more sauce than called for, a whole jar.  I like my sauces....
Will definitely prepare again.

text:
Like another user suggested, I subbed italian seasoned breadcrumbs (whole wheat in this case) for the panko.  I also added a little butter to the frying oil, and used parsley and a little oregano and marjoram in lieu of basil because it was all we had.  If you don't have a meat mallet, just use a heavy rolling pin (we also found parchment paper works really well over the chicken while you are whacking away at it, if you don't have any heavy plastic on hand).

text:
I made a few changes. I used Italian bread crumbs rather than panko because it's already seasoned.  I mixed 1/2 of the parmesan and 1/2 of the Italian bread crumbs in equal parts. I don't measure. I fried and baked chicken but I didn't bake the chicken in sauce. (I make my sauce from scratch)
After I pulled my chicken from the oven I immediately sprinkled the chicken with mozzarella. 
I spooned the warm tomatoe sauce over the chicken. I did not want the chicken to be soggy.

text:
This recipe was "phenomenal"!! Watching the video chef john has helped explain a lot more because I am a visual learner :) I just tweeked a few things . Instead of shredded prov I subbed out Gouda which added a nice kick. In addition to the bread crumb mix the parm Panko and Italian seasoning are perfect choices ! Surprisingly the chicken was cooked all the way through at 450 degrees in 20 minutes remaining juicy and I had a couple of thick pieces . Chicken was crispy and using fresh mozz helps it cook the correct time as listed without burning . I served it atop butter garlic  angel hair noodles !! Will definitely keep these tips when making chicken parm ! Thnx Chef John !!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-10-25T01:08:10.903

text:
Yes, I will make it again. I substituted Angelic Sprouted Wheat bread crumbs. I saved an extra pan by preheating the Corning Ware with olive oil and put the chicken tenderloins in that, then in the oven. I flipped them in about 5 minutes, brushed oil on the other side, cooked 5 more minutes. Then I put the sauce and mozzarella cheese for the remaining 10-15 minutes. I used Aldi's Never Any chicken tenderloins, and their Traditional Reggano sauce.

userID:
20387649
Display Name:
coffee1st
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

2

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tip:  Use small balls fresh mozzarella cheese (often labeled bocconcini) vs. shredded mozzarella.  It melts better, browns better, tastes better.  

Followed recipe exactly - except that I had just made fresh spaghetti sauce from fresh tomatoes (using onions, carrots, etc) so it was more of a "garden" spaghetti sauce, so did not use store bought.  Mine had some crushed red pepper in it so had a lot of zip - I think it complimented this recipe. 

Be SURE to salt/pepper the chicken BEFORE putting in flour -- very important.  It's also an opportunity to use garlic salt or flavored spices instead.

The crust from the panko can't be beat - mine did NOT go soggy in the oven.  I did not smother in sauce - I put the sauce through the middle of the chicken, leaving the ends "exposed" - but made sure the cheese would melt that direction and prevent the ends from over-browning.

If you want the chicken to have a bit more zip - put spices/flavorings into the panko mixture.  One thing I did slightly different is I put the panko crumbs into the remaining flour (used same plate) - so there was a bit of flour - which I think added to the crispiness and helped the panko really stick.

Will use this recipe again - everyone LOVED it!  Would have given it 4.5 stars - but not an option, and only mama's chicken parm gets 5 stars in my book.  :)
