text:
We really enjoyed this chicken parmesan.  I did make a couple changes.  Panko bread crumbs really have no flavor at all, and 4  cups?!?  I used about 2 cups and then added 1 cup of Italian seasoned bread crumbs. Maybe this problem is specific to this cook and his stove, but I heated my oil on only medium heat, and 2 minutes per side gave me much darker than a golden brown crust. Medium high heat would have given me a black crust cooking for 2 mins per side.

text:
This is a great recipe!! My husband is NOT a fan of spaghetti noodles and he absolutely LOVED this when I made it!! So much that he ate it leftover (something he also never does) AND asked for it again already :-)) I earned the nickname"Jama Childs" with this one! Lol Followed the recipe exactly and it came out great both times. Of course, the recipe does not mention the noodle part at all but all I did was cook the noodles about 7-8 minutes for all dente, added some olive oil to keep the noodles from sticking together, and sprinkled some sweet basil over them before adding the chicken on top. Highly recommend this recipe!!

text:
Great and easy recipe to follow.   My husband had asked me to make Chicken Parmesan  ... I have attempted on my own in the past to make this,  but have never been satisfied with the results.    Found this recipe and decided to give it a whirl.  LOVED IT!  Super easy to make - and delicious every time.   Have already made it twice since finding it 2 weeks ago! lol  I highly recommend giving this one a shot!


**Note ** another review said using Fresh Mozzarella was not a good idea - I disagree - I used fresh mozzarella (Sliced - not a round Ball) and it cooks up perfect every time -   browns up a bit - so good!  Also it was stated flour is not needed to coat the chicken - it really does make a difference... the flour adheres to the chicken, allowing the egg to adhere , allowing the dreading to adhere.  So Unless you have a restriction to using it - the minimal amount you need is worth it. :)  Just my two cents :)

text:
Made this recently and loved it!  My husband and I were debating over who got to take the leftover to lunch the next day!  I followed the recipe just about exactly as written, and I was fortunate to have fresh basil straight from the garden.  I did load up on the mozzarella because I was trying to use up what I bought.  Lately, I've been trying coconut oil so I did end up doing the initial "fry" in it, and it worked wonderfully---very little splatter and good flavor.  I served the finished product over angel hair pasta.  So good!  The only thing I'd possibly change next time is to measure out fewer panko crumbs because I had a lot leftover after the egg/flour/crumb coating process.

text:
I gave it 4 stars because it's a good recipe but I did make some significant changes... I used Italian flavored bread crumbs (I cut the amount in half and still did not use it all) with added garlic and dried basil (because that's what I had on hand). I also used our favorite spaghetti sauce (garlic, onion and mushroom flavors) I skipped the provolone all together. The Parmesan and breadcrumb coating is delicious. I didn't let the chicken sit for 15 min before frying and I did fry in half butter half olive oil (the butter did turn brown so if you don't like that then skip the butter). Also, I boiled the pasta and added that to the casserole dish before baking the chicken. I heat up the rest of the spaghetti sauce and we added that on top once it was finished in the oven (we like it saucey). Also... I did use fresh mozzarella and it was wonderful!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I decided to make this at the last minute, wanting to use up some fresh mozzarella that was in my refrigerator.  I basically followed the recipe as written but substituted tomato sauce with Pomi (Italian) strained tomatoes and added a little extra spice (basil, oregano & seasoned pepper).

I cut each chicken breast in 3-4 pieces, flattened them, sprinkled with flour, salt & pepper, dipped in egg, then panko/breadcrumb/parmesan cheese mixture.  I did need a little extra panko/(home-made) breadcrumb mixture.     After sitting for 10 minutes, I pan fried in oil on med/high making the outside crispy quickly.

Then transferred to oven dish and topped each piece in basil, strained tomatoes, mozzarella + sprinkle of fresh grated parmesan + drizzle of olive oil.

Baked at 400 for 15-20 minutes.  Yum Yum.  Will make again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for 18 people and had to make the breasts the day before, transport the entire dish and finish it on-site. I kept the marinara sauce and finishing cheeses separate as to reduce the chance of overly saucy chicken - EVERYONE loved this! Here are my additions: 
> Brine the breasts. I only had time to brine for three hours, but it really kept them juicy. I added fresh oregano sprigs to the otherwise basic brine.
> Home-made sauce. Hey... if you are going to do it, why not ad an hour to make it truly home-made?
> Fried in lard + shortening (50/50) - WHY haven't I tried this before? Crispy and super flavorful! Did it in a large dutch oven and was able to do two breasts at once. Candy thermometer is a MUST!
Thanks, Chef John, for another great recipe!

Once it's out, I sprinkle with grated Parmesan.  Newbies, remember to use an oven mit when removing pan from oven!

text:
User rebeccad has the perfect review for this recipe. You have to use common sense modifications - like putting the fresh basil on when you put in the oven will end up burning the basil. I didn't have a mallet to pound the chicken with, so I just butterflied the breast and they ended up nice and juicy. I didn't use 4 cups of panko because I only have 4 breasts and I didn't need but liked 2.5 cups. I needed more tomato sauce because when I butterflied the chicken it made them twice as large surface area wise. They turned out wonderful tho - a bit hit for dinner that night! Moist chicken, great flavor, and professional presentation.

text:
Great recipe, delicious, will be making again FOR SURE! Changes I made: used half italian seasoned bread crumbs and half regular bread crumbs, SO GOOD. 3 eggs instead of 2, because I made 6 chicken breasts. Cooked up some angel hair pasta to put the chicken on. Used a pre made spicy tomato sauce (also REALLY good).

 Only changes I will make: had WAY TOO MUCH breadcrumb mixture left over (and I even made 6 chicken breasts). So I will be cutting that in half that next time. OVERALL SO SO GOOD!

Best Chicken Parmesan - EVER!!!!  I made this recipe using Italian Seasoned Panko Bread Crumbs.  Not only was it amazing, it was without reservation the very best Chicken Parmesan I have ever had anywhere, and I made it.  I'm not one to toot my own horn but this recipe was beautifully crafted from start to finish. The recipe itself was well written, had precise steps to follow and lent itself to resizing without any issues at all.  I made it for two using a single large chicken breast that I cut into two generous sized portions.
The texture, finish and flavor were without comparison.  Delicious....

This is the first time I have ever made "actual" chicken Parmesan! I've baked chicken and thrown pasta sauce over it and called it chicken cacciatore, add some cheese and called it chicken Parmasen ! What I have missed out all these years, I'm embarrassed to say!
Chef John I have to say this is the best chicken parm I have ever eaten!  
I ALWAYS try the allrecipes recipes to the tee! If from there it's not to my satisfaction then the next time, I might add a bit more heat or a bit more of this or that! 
Some of the reviews are so out there it's no longer "the recipe"!! Why do they do this? 
Chef John this was so amazing I wouldn't change a thing! 
I love how you "season the chicken" and not the bread crumbs!! KUDOS

text:
This recipe is mind blowingly delicious! This was my first time making chicken Parmesan and certainly will not be my last. I changed a couple things. I used Italian flavored bread crumbs instead of Panko and did two layers of egg wash/bread crumbs for a thicker crust. I then deep fried instead of baking. I used canned spaghetti sauce (spinach and cheese) and used shredded marble and Romano cheese and had no fresh basil so I just used basil leaves I had in my cupboard. Baked it to melt the cheese and this was amazing!

Easy & delicious! I followed the recipe for the most part & the chicken turned out crispy on the outside & juicy inside! I made a few adjustments based on the reviews...I used Italian spices panko, a bag of Italian cheeses instead of mozzarella & provolone separate, & put the basil on after it came out of the oven instead of before. Easy, fun, & tasty weeknight dinner the kids loved to help with!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the absolutely most delicious  Parmesan Chicken recipe I've ever made. The chicken breading was crisp and the chicken was very moist. Be sure to let the chicken sit 15 minutes before browning in the pan and  only brown 2 minutes per side. I also only roasted in the oven for 10 minutes.. I have a commercial grade Thermadore oven and it cooks really quick. I would reccomed checking after 10 minutes to see if done. No one wants tough dried out chicken. I also think adding olive oil before  baking is a great idea. I will make this recipe over and over for years to come.

text:
I loved it, the key was to go easy on the sauce. I did just under a double recipe and instead of grated provolone, I just sliced a small wheel into strips. I used a lightly smoked Provolones which really stirred up the flavors. Pretty labor intensive but I managed to cook some roasted Asparagus and a pot of pasta to go with it, so the recipe has plenty of opportunities for a pause or for multitasking. Absolutely stunning flavors, I'll make this again.

text:
I made this meal using RebeccaD's suggestion and it turned out great and used just enough of everything. For 10 chicken halves I only needed 4 eggs and 2 cups of Panko bread crumbs and 1/2 cup of parmesan was exactly enough to coat the 10 breasts. I skipped the salt, pepper and flour and it turned out fine. I made the Chicken Parmesan with Fettucine noodles and it made for a great dinner.

text:
I kind of messed up making the recipe, but it still came out great. I also cooked everything in one pan (cast iron). The panko crumbs give the chicken a nice crust. My husband appreciated having less sauce and we truly enjoyed the dish--as usual great flavor with Chef John's recipes.
 
I used 2 cups panko bread crumbs mixed with grated parmesean/romano cheese. I chopped fresh basil with garlic and a little olive oil, but realized this was not going to mix up evenly with the panko by hand. So, I tossed the panko into my chopper with the basil/garlic/oil, which yes did turn the crumbs greenish,  but who cares no one's going to see it once it's covered with sauce and cheese.

text:
Family loved it.  My only comment, which I can't believe wasn't   mentioned before, is inconsistency in directions. First, 2 cups of panko crumbs is more than enough. I added seasoned crumbs because I didn't have enough plain. Great flavor so I would recommend using 1 cup plain and 1 cup seasoned panko crumbs. Also in the list of ingredients it calls for  1/2 cup prepared tomato sauce but in the directions it states to top each of the four chicken breasts with 1/3 cup. I used the 1/3 cup so used 1 1/3 cups of sauce. 
I definitely will be making this often.

text:
It was decent, especially for those who aren't a big fan of tomato sauce.  However, as others noted, it did come out a little bland.  Next time I'm going to try some additional spices, along with an additional cheese as a top coating (maybe Romano).

I would also note that the prep time is way off.  As an amateur I spent well over an hour, working at a leisurely pace.  Granted I did a little hunting and searching for ingredients, but I doubt I could have finished prep in less than 30 minutes even if rushing wildly.  It took 20 minutes just to unpackage the chicken, cut and trim the fat, and then properly tenderize and spice.

I will make this recipe again in the future, but with some modifications.

You have the basics here and it's definitely been improved upon. Definitely use Italian bread crumbs with the Panko. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an ok basic recipe. Like other reviewers mentioned I ended up with 7 chicken breasts bc I had to cut some in half so they weren't huge. I only used 1 cup  breadcrumbs. Other things I did to give more flavor was add stewed tomatoes to my sauce and black pepper and garlic powder. Also there is no way the bake time is long enough. I had to bake the chicken about 15-20 mins longer than the recipe stated. Also, I didn't follow exactly the amount of sauce I like nothing dry so I used way more sauce on the chicken before putting in oven. Lastly, I didn't follow the amount of Parmesan and mozzarella to be put onto the chicken before putting it in the oven. I just averaged and covered my chicken pieces liberally. Also, used shredded mozzarella bc wouldn't that melt easier and more evenly than cubes? Sure enough it came out great, will make again but with my tweaks.

Display Name:
katergil

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved this recipe.  As far as taste, we agreed that this is  5 star recipe. It was crispier and lighter on the sauce, but plenty rich and balanced both flavor and texture-wise. We will absolutely make this again. 

The recipe itself had a few points that needed clarification. The panko breading made too much, and it's not like you can reuse it once the raw protein comes in contact with it. You could get away with using just 1 cup and just add a pinch more parm to additional panko as needed. That is a common sense alteration, but heads up for those making this style dish for the first time! The second thing I'd have appreciated is the chicken having a weight measurement in the recipe as well since some people may be using tenderloins/frozen/portioning/huge breasts. That said, 1.5 lbs of chicken worked for us!
Review:

5

All in all a definite   keeper and will be making at least once a month. Thank you for the recipe!

Display Name:
Chuck Sampson

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1883590.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I enjoyed this recipe. I had to make a change in the amount of panko. I only used 2 cups of panko, which was more than enough.  And of course reducing the amount of parmesan. I breaded 8 breast fillets with still enough to do at least one more. I didn't use a sifter for the flour to apply to the chicken, I just dredged it. I used Prego's Roasted Garlic & Herb sauce, as the prepared sauce. The author of this recipe wanted a more crunchy chicken, this is why it didn't have much sauce. But for me, there was just not enough sauce, so I added much more to include saucing the bottom of my baking dish before I put the chicken in it.  Then topping  each piece of chicken with more sauce. The flavor was great. I placed a slice of Provolone ( Sargento's ) instead of shredded provolone, and then adding the mozzarella cubes. Served it up on a bed of angel hair pasta....my family really enjoyed it.
Review:

text:
Great dish!!  Don't cook the chicken before baking with spinach and mushrooms.  It will be dry.  I sautéed the spinach and mushrooms before and then drained the liquid that came out, before placing in the dish.  It's great over brown rice or quinoa.  Last change was I made it with almond four instead of breadcrumbs.  It made it healthy w/o being able to tell it's healthy! My husband and kids LOVED it!!!!

text:
This recipe was awesome!! I made a few changes however... Changes from beginning to end... I did not beat the chicken breast at all... I use breast halves.. I rinsed the meat then dryer it off. Then I placed the flour on it. Dipped in egg. And I used Riz crackers vegi as my crumbs to cover the chicken. I took a big pack of the crackers and beat them into small crumbs with my hand. And continued with the recipe. I put seasoning on the top of both side and let it sit with the Riz on the meat. After 15min I fried lightly and then cont with the recipe. I used ITALIAN mix cheese from Kraft which has all cheeses from the recipe above, taste great!! It came out very good!! Loved loved loved it!

I LOVED this recipe! The chicken was tender and juicy, and had the perfect amount of crunch! I didn't add so much Parmesan cheese, only because I didn't have a lot at the time.  Also I only used 2 cups of panko bread crumbs, and that was still way more than enough. So good! Never thought I would be able to make chicken parm.

text:
I have made this several times over the years and it is great!
How ever this time with the tomatoes ready to pick, and I planted 7 plants have tomatoes everywhere and have given so many to everyone I know and strangers too, I couldn't just go buy tomato sauce when I have so many on my counters, tables and still more to pick so I made the tomato sauce from scratch, time consuming but well worth it. I know I will make this sauce and can some so I can live up to the raves the next time I make this dish. Go get tomatoes and have fun, they are available this time of year and cheaper than  the jar sauce. Support your local CSA and farmers market. This makes you a great cook.

My husband and I loved this recipe, even though I had to sub colby jack for the mozzarella  (I know! But it's what I had) and I only had dried basil. Used thin cut chicken breasts and 20 minutes was more than enough at our 3800ft elevation. It was over 200 degrees according to the thermometer, but the browning before baking kept it juicy and tender. Definitely making this one again, and I'll make sure to have fresh mozza next time!

Really great Chicken Parmesan! I made this when we had our friends over for dinner (there were 12 of us all together), and it was great because I breaded and fried the chicken ahead of time, then put them on a sheet pan and finished baking in the oven while we had our cocktails and appetizers, and while the pasta cooked. Also works great breading the chicken breasts and then freezing them for those busy weeknights when you're not sure what to make for dinner.

text:
I made this tonight. The reason for the 3 stars is because I made major changes.  I have one person on a low carb diet, so made changes to accommodate.  I used boneless skinless thighs, trimmed all fat.  I did not bread them or brown the meat before baking.  I used a high quality low carb tomato sauce.  Baked them for 21 minutes.  Did not use olive oil at all. I've been told that I'll have to do it again.  Served over spaghetti squash.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/746016.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This construction makes the best Chicken Parm, keeping the breading crunchy and toothsome, not gummy and drowning in a sea of sauce. I copied the assembly from the video exactly. Because I was using cutlets I didn't need extra cooking time in the oven, so stuck them under the broiler to melt the cheese. Made almost as written, scaled for 2 cutlets with 1 cup Panko and ? cup grated Parm. Lacking fresh basil, I amped up the flavor with Italian seasoning added to the Panko mix and a sprinkle of fresh parsley when I plated the cutlets.  I used Chef John's tomato sauce (slightly modified), it is my standard tomato sauce for years and works so well with so many things, Chicken Parm being no exception. Total winner, and completely company-worthy. I served it with some Vermicelli and a salad.

Display Name:
Seth's Mom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight and it was great. I made the following changes after reading reviews. Used half panko and half italian seasoned bread crumbs. I used canola oil and butter to fry in (was out of olive oil.) I bought the kraft shredded italian blend instead of buying all different cheeses and omitted the basil.  I fried 1.5min on each side, transferred to baking dish and cooked 15min at 425 before added marinara/cheese. I would highly suggest a glass dish and not metal pan. My chicken were so large I had to cook one in a separate pan which ended up being metal and it crisped the chicken too much so I took it out early. After 15min added marinara (Ragu brand tomato, garlic, onion) and the blended cheese and broiled for 2min. Served with angel hair pasta and garlic bread. Will do it again but will use smaller chicken breast next time. We will have left overs for days

text:
I will be making these again for sure. Nice and crispy and not all breading (I hate that). I added some spices to the tomato sauce (garlic powder. Dash of onion powder, some Italian seasoning, and white pepper). I also added in some dried parsley and oregano to the bread crumb mixture, and pepper to the flour mixture. I really think the secret is leaving them sit for 15 minutes after breading and before frying. I didn't have provolone, but I can't wait to try it with provolone along with the mixer ell and parm cheese the next time! Easy, fast and tasty make this a perfect dinner.

This is a winner.  I tried to double this and messed it up a little (user error!), and it STILL came out fantastic.  My family loved it and declared it the best chicken parm they've ever had, even better than restaurants. I love that it doesn't use a ton of red sauce, because you can really taste the flavors in the chicken which is how it should be.  The breaded chicken part of the recipe is a great staple to have in your repertoire that would also be delicious with a lemon butter sauce and capers for kind of a spin-off of Chicken Piccata.

Oh my goodness! How did I get to this age and NOT have this before? It was amazing! I followed the recipe almost exactly, with a few minor changes based on what was in my kitchen. I was using 4 huge chicken breasts so I had to add some flour to my panko. I also added about 3 tablespoons of spicy spaghetti seasoning to the bread crumbs. Probably the best chicken parmesan recipe we ever tried!! Kids and hubby loved it, panko really makes a huge difference in how crispy the chicken comes out, I followed the recipe exactly the same although I did add italian seasoned breadcrumbs to the panko for more flavour, make sure to season your chicken well with salt and pepper on both sides before dipping in the mixtures.  Next time I would half the amount of bread crumbs, I ended up with a lot leftover after I was done and I had to throw it all out.  Will make again.

Display Name:
mjwolffdmd

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used the parmesan grated into seasoned breadcrumbs since that is all I had at home. It was dark golden brown, finished in oven, used pesto on 2 of the breasts,and my quick homemade sauce with crushed tomatoes, onions, garlic, thyme, oregano, salt and pepper. The sauce was simple but flavorful enough, added the cheese and pesto, and more freshly grated provolone and parmegiano reggiano on top. baked at 450 degrees for about 10 mins, until the cheese was slightly golden. the chicken was juicy, moist and crust was crunchy. my husband loved it. we did not serve any sides as the breast was very large to begin with. would make again with more changes/tweaks next time. but nothing beats a homemade sauce! i think that and the fresh italian cheeses are what make the difference. oh and not to waste the leftover breadcrumbs i just added one egg to it and made a large flat patty and fried it like my grandmother used to because i was so hungry so i'd have something to eat while waiting for the chicken to cook. it's a tradition in my family and new for my husband and he absolutely loved it!try it you'll love it too!

I followed the recipe exactly as is (although I lacked both the parmesan cheese and fresh basil at that time) and I thought it was flavorful and scrumptious. Like one reviewer said, one egg could have sufficed as I had enough left over and the same could be said for the cups of panko provided you were only cooking 4 chicken breasts. text:
Very tasty.The video with tips was very helpful. I followed other reviewer's recommendation to add the cheese for the last five minutes of baking. I omitted the olive oil on top with the cheese; it was not needed. I made 6 chicken breasts with the two eggs and still had leftover egg, so probably could get away with one egg for 4 breasts. Also I used whole wheat bread crumbs.
Next time I will try healthy methods...1) use egg beaters and 2) maybe broil the chicken with a bit of olive oil rather than fry in excess oil 3) also will consider an alternate breading.

text:
I wound up running out of Panko, so I substituted 3 cups of crushed cornflakes, and mixed it in with the cup of Panko. I still only used half of the 4 cups, even with double breading them. I baked them instead of frying, mostly to cut a few calories. I baked it in the pre-heated 450 oven for 15-20 minutes and then proceeded with the recipe as written. I did wind up with four humongous fillets, and would do like another reviewer and cut them in half next time.

I have made this very similar, just that I season the panko with freeze dried basil and Italian herbs. I put the chicken on a baking sheet and drizzle with olive oil. I have my marinara sauce already hot so when I transfer to a baking dish I top with the sauce and mozzarella(I like to slice mine little thick) and when it's melted it's ready to serve. text:
This recipe is wonderful.  You do not need 4 cups of panko crumbs.  I had to throw away about 2 cups.  The only thing different that I did was I only used 3 large chicken breast which I pounded out and then cut in half so it made 6 good size portions.  I used 3 cups of panko and one of seasoned bread crumbs (which I will reduce to a total of two cups next time).  I did not use 1 cup of olive oil to brown chicken breast.  I only used about 1/2 cup.  I will make this again.

userID:
2011883
Display Name:
grampnana
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2583840.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great and easy way to create a totally different meal from left-over spaghetti sauce.  Purchased four pre-thinned chicken breasts to make it even easier; used a mix of Italian bread crumbs and lemon pepper panko and mixed in some granulated onion and garlic; used Wondra flour, as it has a built-in sifter-type spout; only used one egg, which was barely enough but didn't want to waste the large part of a second one; did not measure the olive oil for browning; only used shredded mozzarella, which was on hand, in place of the cubed and provolone and Parmesan mix; placed left over penne in bottom of casserole, placed breasts on top, covered with spaghetti sauce, then shredded cheese, and covered for entire baking time of about 25 minutes.  Do not understand the instructions of covering each of 4 breasts with 1/3 cup sauce, when ingredients only call for a total of 1/2 cup sauce, but had much more spaghetti sauce on hand anyway, so it was not a problem for me - others should be aware.  Am really making this review so tedious to remember how I did it, as it turned out quite tasty and even picky meat eater hubby liked it quite a bit.  Thanks for sharing this tasty meal

text:
Made this earlier in the week with the following mods: 1) Did not fry in olive oil, instead, placed prepared chicken on rack on top of cookie sheet, misted each with olive oil, baked for 20 minutes at 350, then turned over and baked at 450 until browned (only took a few minutes); 2) topped only with homemade sauce and mozzarella, continued to bake until cheese was bubbly and began to brown; 3) served with spaghetti in sauce topped with a drizzle of olive oil and fresh grated pecorino romano.  Compliments on this dish - The best dish I've ever made; Better than Olive Garden. It was delicious!  Will make again.

text:
Very good dish. I added many more herbs instead of the fresh basil since I had none and it came out well. I thought that 1 cup of olive oil would be too much so I used less than 1/2 cup. Also, I did not drizzle the breasts with oil before baking; I added a little more mozzarella than what was indicated and served the dish with a good-quality marinara on the side. My husband told me that this was the best Chicken Parmigiana he's ever had. Reason enough for a replay later.

text:
Very good recipe, and will make this again soon. My very picky guy unfortunately prefers regular bread crumbs to the panko, so we're going to try this with plain bread crumbs next time around. I personally loved the panko for the extra crisp. 

The only difficulty that I had was that it's very cumbersome to grate provolone, since it's so soft (or is it just me?). I also had way too much of the panko mixture leftover. I would make only about 2/3 of the original recipe's panko-parmesan mixture for next time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was so good! I am just starting to learn how to cook and this recipe was very easy to follow, had very exact proportions and was not very difficult. A little messy on your first try, but this is perfect if you need to cook a bigger meal because you can prepare almost everything ahead of time. I could never find shredded provolone, so I had the circular ones and chopped them up everything and it still tastes wonderful. I also couldn't really use fresh basil or fresh mozzarella every time, and it was never an issue. This dish is also good to eat as leftovers, it doesn't have any weird taste after being in the fridge for an hour or two and it a great lunch for work or late night snack. I personally prefer the chicken to be thickly coated with the Hunt's tomato sauce so I use a little bit more, but that's a personal choice. I feel like this recipe is hard to mess up and has a large margin for error if you don't have you proportions exactly correct. Love Chef John!
